div1.p: Truby agrees to work on an estimate of the cost of the Yellow Fever Commission expenses.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 5, 1953
div1.opener:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
March 5, 1953
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of February 20 has had to be side-tracked because
of an acute attack of lumbago which has crippled me up so that
I have hardly been able to navigate. It is much better and I
think I have it licked.

I will be very much interested to work on an estimate of the
cost of Reed's Yellow Fever Board expenses, i.e., the cost of
his experiments. However, you must not expect me to work fast
because I just can't hurry but I'll tackle it by getting together
some estimates of the number of men he had, whether they worked
there full time or part time, and also get a line on the equip-
ment they borrowed from us and which came from Havana. The cost
of the rental of the land, I think you have the figures on that
and the money paid to the men for volunteering. The two wooden
buildings, tent floors, etc. were, I think, all left there.
I'll get together some figures on various things of that kind and
then make my tentative estimate to discuss with you. It will be
quite interesting I am sure. I am sure there should be something
about it in General Wood's annual reports for the years 1900 and
1901. I have the 1901 report and I will go through it carefully
at once. It should be there.

Have you any idea when you would want this finished? When you
have some leisure time think it over and let me know.

In your letter of February 18, you mentioned that Dr. Nogueira
is himself writing a book, so I have no desire to bother him about
my book and will tell him to forget it. I have not heard from him
since I wrote to him about this and I do not know whether he has
received the photographs I sent him or not. The photographs were
sent airmail and registered but I think it went marked second class
mail. The chances are it did not go airmail. Anyway, they should
be there by this time. No doubt, I will hear from Pedro very soon.
No word has been received as to when the medals will be delivered.

I have already found in General Wood's report that the yellow
fever camp had a telephone.
I hope that my plans will meet your approval. With best regards,

closer.seg:
P. S. In my scrapbook which is nicely bound in red. I have
collected important letters and papers connected with my story.
You saw this book and were interested in Dr Ravenel's
letters etc. Before you publish your book you should go through
(over)
it again. Shall I send it now and you can keep it with
your other files of info re Reed's work?
A E T
